Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: I glanced at my phone during my break, reading my wife’s message: “Rough day, nothing major, just tired. Miss you.” I wanted to call her, to listen and reassure her, to be the husband she needed. But the line at the register was growing, and my break was almost over. I tucked my phone away, forcing a smile as I returned to the counter. The next customer slammed her groceries down, voice sharp and impatient. I could feel my own stress rising, but I knew I had to stay calm, friendly, patient—what the store expected of me. My mind kept drifting to my wife, picturing her alone on the couch, waiting for a kind word. I felt torn, pulled between the need to be present for her and the demand to serve each customer with a smile. My heart ached with guilt and frustration, wishing I could be in two places at once, knowing I had to choose which role to fulfill in this moment.
